title: 109_s2783
content: The Act is titled the "Gulf of Mexico Restoration and Protection Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The Gulf of Mexico is a valuable national and international resource, serving as a source of food, economic productivity, and recreation. Pollution from various sources has diminished its productivity and water quality. The US aims to protect and restore the Gulf ecosystem through collaborative efforts. The Gulf of Mexico Program aims to expand and strengthen cooperative efforts to restore and protect the Gulf, enhance Federal support for monitoring and restoration activities, improve water quality and living resources, and establish a model for collaborative ecosystem management. SEC. 123. GULF OF MEXICO RESTORATION AND PROTECTION. This section amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to focus on restoration and protection efforts in the Gulf of Mexico. The Gulf of Mexico ecosystem, Gulf of Mexico Executive Council, Program, and Program Office are defined terms within the Gulf of Mexico Program established in 1988. The Program focuses on primary environmental issues affecting the Gulf of Mexico. The Gulf of Mexico Program Office is reestablished under the Environmental Protection Agency, headed by a Director with expertise in Gulf of Mexico issues. The Gulf of Mexico Program Office, located in a Gulf Coast state, coordinates actions to improve water quality and living resources in the Gulf ecosystem. The Gulf of Mexico Program Office, located in a Gulf Coast state, coordinates actions to improve water quality and living resources in the Gulf ecosystem by assisting in developing action plans, implementing restoration projects, facilitating research activities, conducting outreach programs, and providing public information and education. The Gulf of Mexico Program Office coordinates actions to improve environmental quality and living resources in the Gulf ecosystem by providing information, technical assistance, and serving as a liaison with Mexican counterparts. The Administrator may enter into interagency agreements and provide grants to nonprofit organizations. The Administrator may provide grants to various entities for monitoring, researching, developing cooperative strategies, and implementing protection and restoration programs in the Gulf of Mexico ecosystem. The Administrator may provide grants for projects in the Gulf of Mexico ecosystem, focusing on habitat creation, restoration, protection, and pollution reduction. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 75 percent, and administrative costs are limited to salaries and overhead. The Director of the Program Office must submit an annual report detailing projects funded under the grant, their goals, objectives, and net benefits. Administrative costs for projects should not exceed 15 percent of the grant amount. The Administrator, in coordination with the Gulf of Mexico Executive Council, must complete an assessment and submit a report to Congress every 5 years on the performance of the Program. The report should assess the Gulf of Mexico ecosystem, compare it with a baseline assessment, and evaluate the effectiveness of Program management strategies. The Administrator must assess the Gulf of Mexico ecosystem every 5 years and report to Congress on the Program's performance, including recommendations for improved management. A separate budget line item request for the Program Office should be included in the annual EPA budget submission. Authorization of appropriations includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2006 and $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2007. The authorization of appropriations for the Gulf of Mexico ecosystem assessment includes $25,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2008 through 2010.
